and there's a few reasons for
that the first is that when we started
trying to eradicate polio about 20 years
ago more than twice as many countries
were infected than had been when we
started off with small poox and there
were more than 10 times as many people
living in these countries so it was a
massive effort the Second Challenge we
had was in contrast to the small poox
vaccine which was very stable and a
single dose protected you for life the
polio vaccine is incredibly fragile AG
it deteriorates so quickly in the
tropics that we've had to put the
special vaccine monitor on every single
vial so that it will change very quickly
when it's exposed to too much heat and
we can tell that it's not a good vaccine
to use on a child it's not potent it's
not going to protect them even then kids
need many doses of the vaccine but the
third challenge we have and probably

that in contrast to small pox where you

poox had this Telltale rash so you could
get around the disease you could
vaccinate around the disease and cut it
off polio it's almost completely
different the vast majority of people
who are infected with the polio virus
show absolutely no sign of the disease
so you can't see the enemy most of the
time and as a result we've needed a very
different approach to eradicate polio
than what was done with small poox we've
had to create one of the largest social

people vaccinate over 500 million
children every single year multiple
times at the peak of our
operations now giving the polio vaccine
is simple just two drops like that but
reaching 500 million people is much much
